note.p: John Marshall Stone served as governor of Mississippi two separate times, from 1876 to 1882 and from 1890 to 1896.

Born in Milan, Tennessee, on March 29, 1876, Stone grew up mostly in poverty but worked for his education and eventually became a school teacher. He moved to Mississippi in the mid-1850s and found work as a railroad station agent at Iuka, Mississippi. When the Civil War broke out in 1861, Stone joined the Confederate army. He was placed in command of Company K of the 2nd Mississippi Infantry Regiment. Proving capable in battle during campaigns in Virginia, he was promoted in 1862 to colonel of the regiment and received high praise from his superiors during the rest of the war. Stone led his regiment until near the end of the war, when he was captured in North Carolina and sent to Ohio as a prisoner.

Upon his release after the Civil War, Stone returned to Mississippi and resumed his work with the Mississippi and Ohio Railroad at Iuka. He married Mary G. Coman in 1872 and had two children, both of whom died before adulthood. Stone and his wife also adopted and raised three of his nephews.

He entered politics in 1869, winning election to the Mississippi state senate as a Democrat. In 1873 and 1874, Democrats in Mississippi gained majority power following campaigns of voter intimidation and violence against African Americans and Republicans. Stone worked his way to president pro tempore of the Senate during this period. In 1876, the Democrat majority in the state legislature carried out an impeachment campaign against top Republican officials, including Governor Adelbert Ames and Lieutenant Governor Alexander K. Davis. When Davis was impeached and Ames was forced to resign to avoid a costly lawsuit against politically-driven impeachment charges, Stone became next in line for governor. He was sworn into office in March 1876.

Stone served as acting-governor for a year and a half and then won the gubernatorial election in 1877, running as the sole candidate. He lost reelection in 1881 to Robert Lowry, but retained his interest in the governor’s office and ran again—and won—in 1889. Mississippi adopted a new constitution in 1890, which in part extended Stone’s gubernatorial term until 1896 to aid the transition of new policies. The new constitution prohibited successive gubernatorial terms. Thus, Stone could not run for immediate reelection. Upon leaving office, he received an appointment as president of the Mississippi Agricultural and Mechanical College (now Mississippi State University) in Starkville. He died in 1900 and is buried at Oak Grove Cemetery in Iuka, Mississippi.
(Wikipedia; Dan Sansing, “John Marshall Stone: Thirty-first and Thirty-third Governor of Mississippi: 1876-1882; 1890–1896,” Mississippi History Now)

Kinloch Falconer was active in Democratic politics in Mississippi during Reconstruction and served as Mississippi’s secretary of state in 1878.

Born on October 28, 1838, Falconer grew up in Holly Springs, Mississippi. As a young man he worked at the Southern Herald (his father’s newspaper) and attended the University of Mississippi, graduating in 1860 on the eve of the Civil War. When the war broke out, Falconer enlisted in the 9th Mississippi Infantry Regiment. Recognized for his intelligence and writing ability, Falconer was soon promoted and moved to administrative and staff work, first serving as the private secretary and then adjutant general for Confederate General Braxton Bragg. Later he served as a staff officer for Confederate General Joseph E. Johnston during the Atlanta Campaign in the summer of 1864.

After the defeat of the Confederacy, Falconer returned to Mississippi and reentered the newspaper business, becoming editor of the Holly Springs Reporter. He began fostering an interest state politics and unsuccessfully ran for lieutenant governor as a Democrat under Benjamin G. Humphreys in 1868. In 1870, Falconer stepped away from editorial duties at the Reporter to practice law full time. He continued participating in Democratic politics and in 1877 was elected secretary of state. He entered that office in January 1878. However, only a few months later, a yellow fever epidemic struck parts of Mississippi. Falconer’s brother and father were stricken by the mosquito-borne disease. He went to Holly Springs to aid in their care, but both men died. Falconer himself then came down with the disease and died on September 23, 1878. He is buried in Hill Crest Cemetery in Holly Springs, Mississippi.

(The Daily Clarion, Meridian, MS, June 22, 1864; The Grenada Sentinel, Grenada, MS, May 16, 1868; The Clarion, Jackson, MS, February 3, 1870; The. Clarion-Ledger, Jackson, MS, November 6, 1878; Wikipedia; FindaGrave)

gloss.p: Engaging in "illegal activities." (Cambridge Dictionary)

Conspiracy is an agreement, or plan, between two or more people to commit a criminal action. Frequently, conviction of conspiracy requires at least one of the conspirators to have committed an illegal act. In such cases, fellow conspirators may face similar charges and punishment even if they did not carry out the crime.

A notable example of criminal conspiracy from the Civil War and Reconstruction eras involves the assassination of President Abraham Lincoln. While John Wilkes Booth alone shot and killed Lincoln, federal officials learned that Booth had conspired with several Confederate sympathizers to first kidnap the president, and later to assassinate Lincoln and other federal officials. Federal and military officials arrested numerous people suspected of being part of the plot. Ultimately, eight people were arrested and tried by a military tribunal. Four were sentenced to life in prison and the other four were sentenced to death. Only one of the convicted prisoners from this trial had committed a violent act (Lewis Powell had tried to assassinate Secretary of State William Seward); the others were found guilty due to their knowledge of, and participation in, plans against Lincoln and the U.S. government.

During Reconstruction, Republican officials also passed laws to prevent, or punish, conspiracies by white southerners designed to disenfranchise African Americans or undermine federal policies. For instance, the Enforcement Act of 1871 (also known as the Ku Klux Klan Act) made intimidation acts by secret or terrorist groups, like the Ku Klux Klan, federal offenses and authorized the president to use military forces to suppress these groups and conspiracies against federal policies. This effort severely reduced the success of groups like the Ku Klux Klan to conspire against Black southerners, at least before the end of Reconstruction. (Wikipedia)
A crime defined as "the act of killing someone without a legal trial, usually by hanging." (Cambridge Dictionary)
Suggesting "that something unpleasant or violent will happen, especially if a particular action or order is not followed." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"The illegal act of causing immense physical and or mental pain in order to persuade another person." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"The processing of individuals who have committed criminal acts." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"The hearing of statements and showing of objects, etc. in a law court to judge if a person is guilty of a crime or to decide a case or a legal matter." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"Individuals responsible for enforcing laws in designated areas." (Cambridge Dictionary)
"In the U.S., an official whose job is to be in charge of performing the orders of the law courts and making certain that the laws are obeyed within a particular county." (Cambridge Dictionary)

“Someone who works in an office, writing letters, making phone calls, and arranging meetings for a person or for an organization.” (Cambridge Dictionary) CWRGM includes people who perform administrative assistance under this tag, but we do not include government positions that incorporate the word secretary, such as Secretary of State, under this subject tag.

Operating at the state level, the Executive Department of the State of Mississippi consists of the governor, lieutenant governor, secretary of state, state treasurer, state comptroller, commissioner of agriculture, commissioner of insurance, the Mississippi Public Service Commission, the Mississippi Transportation Commission, and attorney general. Each official is elected for a four-year term and is appointed duties pertaining to state regulations. (Wikipedia)

gloss.p: A paramilitary organization is a group of armed individuals that act in a pseudo-military fashion, but is not an official military unit. Paramilitary groups are often associated with illegal or revolutionary actions, and frequently use guerilla warfare or even terrorism to achieve their objectives. The term paramilitary arose in the twentieth century, however examples of paramilitary-style groups during the Civil War include Missouri Bushwhackers and Kansas Jayhawkers, who engaged in guerilla warfare, and sometimes terrorist or criminal actions, ostensibly for their respective side. Some of these units were eventually accepted into formal military service within the Union and Confederate armies, while others operated with only tacit endorsement by the warring governments.

Paramilitary groups are more commonly associated to the Reconstruction era, when bands of armed citizens in the south organized to resist state and federal authorities who supported Republican policies. The most well-known examples include the Ku Klux Klan, the White League, and the Red Shirts. The Klan started as a fraternal order in 1865 among former Confederate soldiers in Tennessee but rapidly became a terrorist group, whose members often wore hoods to hide their identities. It became the most famous group dedicated to intimidating Republicans and African Americans in the south to maintain white supremacy. The White League was formed in the early 1870s in Louisiana, but spread openly across the south for the purpose of using violence to intimidate Republican officials and Black southerners who challenged white supremacy. The White League grew so strong as a paramilitary group that it mustered 5,000 members to outnumber and defeat the New Orleans police force and a state militia unit in a battle in New Orleans in 1873. The Red Shirts emerged around 1875 in Mississippi to oppose Republican Reconstruction and, likewise, enforce white supremacy over Black southerners, often through demonstrations at voting centers. These groups, and others in the south during the latter part of the nineteenth century, were organized, armed, and driven by political and social objectives, but were not formal military units or officially part of their state and local governments (even when they were supported by sympathetic officials).

White supremacist paramilitary groups reversed civil rights progress during the last years of Reconstruction and afterwards, and maintained a steady presence for many years, using intimidation and terrorism, to oppose efforts by white and Black southerners seeking racial equality. (Wikipedia)

gloss.p: The Ku Klux Klan (KKK or Klan) is a white supremacist organization that became infamous during the Reconstruction era for terrorizing Black families and Republicans in the south. The Klan was created by former Confederates in Tennessee in December 1865 as a social club that mirrored some fraternal organizations from the mid-nineteenth century. It adopted mystic ceremonies, masks, and eventually white hoods that became the trademark appearance for a Klansman. The Klan spread across the south in the late 1860s, but had little organizational structure above local chapters. Although its original founding may have been more recreational than political, by 1867 the KKK began promoting white supremacy in opposition to the expansion of Black civil rights and Republican Reconstruction. Klan members carried out an insurgency in the south, using threats and violence, including destruction of property and assassinations, to achieve its goals. The use of hoods and fanciful costumes added to the mystique of the Klan, as well as protected the identity of its members during their terrorist activities. The Klan’s reputation for violence and intimidation reached the halls of Congress, leading the federal government to pass three pieces of legislation known as the Enforcement Acts in 1870 and 1871. The third Enforcement Act was known as the “Ku Klux Klan Act” due to its provisions making terroristic threats and intimidation to deny civil rights a federal offense. Additionally, state officials that denied Black southerners equal protection of the law could also be taken to federal court. With these laws, federal agents were empowered to arrest and prosecute Klan members, or anyone else charged with using threats or intimidation to suppress civil rights in the south. The Enforcement Laws were effective in disrupting the Klan’s activities, and reinvigorating federal protection of equal rights. By the mid-1870s the KKK was largely defunct, although it was replaced by other white supremacist organizations. The Klan made a comeback around 1915 and then a third resurgence in the 1950s in response to the Civil Rights movement. It continues to exist in the twenty-first century, but largely as a small, fringe extremist group. (Wikipedia)

gloss.p: Historically free African Americans included people who were both African American and lived as and/or were legally free before the American Civil War. They may or may not have previously been enslaved. In recognition of African American military service during the Revolutionary War, a number of states moved to gradually abolish slavery leading to a growing body of free African Americans.

Freedom, however, did not mean citizenship, and despite efforts by free Black activists to settle this question and affirm their citizenship, it was largely left to state lawmakers who otherwise failed to settle the question. Consequently, during the Antebellum era, each southern state passed different laws governing the place and rights of free African Americans. Home to the nation's largest free African American community, for example, Baltimore, Maryland registered 25,000 free Black residents by 1850. (Martha S. Jones, Birthright Citizens: A History of Race and Rights in Antebellum America, p. 13)

In another example, South Carolina's Act of 1820 distinguished between those freed before and after 1820, and classified free African Americans as "denizens," which limited citizenship rights by a series of Black Codes. In response to rebellions, numerous states passed legal restrictions that made manumission virtually impossible by the mid-nineteenth century. Loved ones who purchased family members were forced to legally hold them in bondage, leading to a body of people who "were free by practice, but not by law." (Amrita Chakrabarti Myers, Forging Freedom, 3–4, 207)

Unlike South Carolina, Mississippi's judiciary ruled that “free negroes . . . are to be regarded as alien enemies or strangers prohibited, and without the pale of comity, and incapable of acquiring or maintaining property in this State which will be recognized by our courts.” (Heirn v. Bridault, 37 Miss. 209, 224–25, 1859 in Jones, Birthright Citizens, p. 213) The state's strict provisions on manumission led to an extremely small population of free African Americans (773 people by 1860) during the antebellum era ("Free Blacks in Antebellum Mississippi," Mississippi Encyclopedia)

Newly freed African Americans includes people who were enslaved but became free by the passage of the Emancipation Proclamation and/or the Thirteenth Amendment. While neither was comprehensive, the Emancipation Proclamation of 1863 freed the enslaved in territories under rebellion, and later the Thirteenth Amendment of 1865 abolished slavery altogether, except when used as a punishment for those who committed a crime and did not apply to Native Nations who practices slavery. (American Battlefield Trust; Wikipedia) In the CWRGM collection, African Americans after December 6, 1865 are classified as historically free or newly freed.

gloss.p: The Cambridge Dictionary classifies "a person who lives in the U.S. and is a member of a race of people with dark skin that originally came from Africa" as African American, but both the nineteenth-century and modern constructions are more complex (Cambridge Dictionary). Common nineteenth-century racial categories such as "mulatto" referred to persons with both white and black ancestry, and the experiences of mixed-race persons varied based on complexion, degree of African ancestry, and the region in which they lived. In antebellum cities with large populations of free Blacks, the degree of one's African ancestry could determine what rights one possessed or did not possess, and people with lighter skin tones were often considered to be white; this ended under "one drop rule" during the Jim Crow system.

Like skin tone, the ethnicity implied by the term "African American" is also problematically broad, as "naming people only by the continent of their origin and ignoring their ethnic identity is a consequence of time and space" (Painter, Creating Black Americans, 5). The experience of slavery complicated the term by attempting to strip people of their original distinct African ethnic identities such as Ibo or Ndongan, classifying all persons of African descent together under one term, infusing that term with negative connotation, and disregarding the complex and rich linguistic, cultural, and ethnic histories of varied African people. However, many Black Americans have reclaimed the term "African American" and infused it with positive connotations. One scholar argues that "in using the term 'African Americans,' Black Americans accent the part of their heritage that is not American" (Painter, Creating Black Americans, 4).

CWRGM — acknowledging the multiplicity of the term's meanings and connotations — includes multiracial and multiethnic people of African descent under the "African Americans" social identifiers subject tag to reflect the diversity of the African American experience and to ensure that the experiences of African Americans of mixed races and ethnicities are discoverable as they are rarely distinguished further in the letters. In the absence of other references, CWRGM also tags racial slurs targeted at African Americans — which were common in nineteenth century documents with white authors — under the "African Americans" tag. CWRGM recognizes the historic and present harm caused by such language and does not condone its use but tags these terms only to ensure the rich history of African Americans are discoverable within the collection.

div.p:
268 Front Street
Memphis 24th" July 1877

His Excell
Governor J M Stone
Jackson
Miss
Dear Sir

I have the honor to acknowledge receipt of your communication of 4th"; and state that my object in delaying answering so long was for the purpose of allowing any angry feeling to subside—In this I have been unfortunate as, on my visit to Friars Point last week, I found bad feeling as rife as ever—
In my communication of 4th ult I wrote you very frankly and desire to maintain the same friendly intercourse.
I remained 11 days in Friars Point subsequent to the receipt of the Kuklux notice and five days after receipt of your letter
div.note: AI Assist generally very accurate, with only a few mistakes. Spacing is good. AI Text also has a few mistakes.

div.p: to me in which you stated that you had directed the attention of the Sheriff to the facts I presented—During that time I looked anxiously to see what steps would be taken by the legally constituted authorities for my protection; but they, the perfectly conversant with the facts and the actors, and even after conversation with parties engaged in the conspiracy, did nothing—I was prepared to cooperate with the authorities and at great inconvenience and in fear of personal violence waited at Friars Point for that purpose—I even prepared an affidavit—Surprising to relate I did not hear one word from the Sheriff and therefore did not go near him—In my judgement it behooved the authorities to notify a consult me as to what steps it seemed most advisable to take—
I cannot accept mere verbal protection—In order that I may feel protected it is necessary that I should see a community put down, attempt so to do or frown down lawless proceedings; and when
div.note: Spacing is good, but both AI Text and AI Assist could improve in accuracy.

div.p: to me

such are frequent and nothing done I must consider that the community wink at the transaction—Legal proceedings and trials amount to a farce when the sympathy of the people is on the side of the participators—
My residence at Friars Point has been short—Short as it has been I will note what has occured during my three months residence and it is for that reason I cannot accept here empty words.
1—Two colored men run out of town—and I have heard boasts made that had they not got away they would have been killed—One of the Actors is now in Chicago & his evidence can be easily obtained—
2—A white man received notice to quit town—This he did on short notice—
3—Several armed men rode town as I was informed for the purpose of having a difficulty with Mr Fert Alcorn—
div.note: Both AI Text and AI Assist have some mistakes.

div.p: 4 A colored man chased and found protection in the house of W Beesly chairman of the Board of Supervisors.
5 A colored man chased about town—The crowd stated they had made a mistake and then treated him to a drink—
6 A white man taken out stripped and blacked.
I say nothing of conversation which is without concealment threatening to drive out any who may be obnoxious.
The above are facts and I can place no confidence in the dicta of a community where such things are tolerated & winked at—

I have been reluctantly compelled to leave Friars Point. My arrangements were made for entering into business there—My personal effects are there—Some goods remain there—I stopped the balance from being shipped there—I have sustained services loss
div.note: AI Assist not available. AI Text struggled with the formatting of the list on this page, and there are several mistakes in the transcription of the body of the text.

div.p: and damage—I find no protection from the arm of the law,—and am reluctantly compelled to apply to you—I wait your decision and until I receive same shall do nothing—

I have the honor to remain
Your Most Obt Servt
